metadata.title: Wells-Dawson heteropoly acid immobilized inside the nanocages of SBA-16 with ship-in-a-bottle method: A new recoverable catalyst for the epoxidation of olefins
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 9815 S1381-1169(16)30083-8 10.1016/j.molcata.2016.03.016 Elsevier B.V. Fig 1 Schematic description of preparation of Wells-Dawson structured heteropoly acid (H6P2W18O62) inside the nanocages of SBA-16 through the “ship-in-a-bottle” method. Fig 1 Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of: (a) H6P2W18O62, (b) SBA-16, and (c) H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Nitrogen sorption isotherms, and (b) BJH pore size distributions of SBA-16, oct-SBA-16, and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TGA-DTA curves of H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM image of H6P2W18O62@SBA-16: (a) along the (111) direction (b) along the (100) direction. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Results of catalytic epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols with H2O2 in the presence of H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. Wells-Dawson heteropoly acid immobilized inside the nanocages of SBA-16 with ship-in-a-bottle method: A new recoverable catalyst for the epoxidation of olefins M. Masteri-Farahani ⁎ M. Modarres Faculty of Chemistry, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran Faculty of Chemistry Kharazmi University Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Wells-Dawson structured heteropoly acid (H6P2W18O64) was immobilized into the SBA-16 mesoporous material by ship-in-a-bottle method. The obtained material was characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission (ICP-AES) spectroscopies, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), nitrogen adsorption–desorption analysis, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA-DTA). The results indicated that the surface area of SBA-16 support decreased after immobilization of the heteropoly acid and next modification with silylating agent. The prepared material exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols in the presence of hydrogen peroxide as green oxidant. The catalyst showed all of the expected advantages of the heterogeneous systems and was shown to be recoverable and reusable several times without major loss of activity. Keywords Mesoporous SBA-16 Wells-Dawson Heteropoly acid Ship-in-a-bottle Epoxidation 1 Introduction In recent years, environmental considerations and handling problems have raised great interest in the development of eco-friendly materials and processes to eliminate the use of harmful substances and the production of toxic waste materials. In this respect, heterogeneous catalysis could play a key role in the development of environmentally benign processes particularly in the petroleum and chemical industries. In terms of green chemistry, high activity of the catalyst is not the only concern, and good reusability and environmental friendliness are also important. Immobilizing soluble homogeneous catalysts on insoluble inorganic supports is a strategic way for preparing heterogeneous solid catalysts [1–3]. Heteropoly acids (HPAs) are well defined molecular clusters that are remarkable for their molecular and electronic structural diversity and their significance is quite diverse in many areas, e.g. catalysis, medicine, and materials science [4–11]. They have been chosen as catalysts because of their easy availability, efficient and cleaner processes compared to conventional mineral acids and extreme stability in solution as well as in solid state. In view of green chemistry, the substitution of harmful liquid acids by HPAs which are also eco-friendly and green catalysts in organic synthesis have attracted great attentions [4,12–18]. HPAs were also found highly efficient for epoxidation of olefins by Venturello et al. [19–22], and Ishii et al. [23,24]. Various H2O2-based epoxidation systems have been efficiently catalyzed by HPAs based systems [19–29]. The main disadvantages of pure HPAs as homogeneous catalysts are their very low surface area in solid state and high solubility in polar solvents, which results in separation problems. It becomes necessary to disperse HPAs on solid supports that possess large surface area [30–39]. Heterogenization of the HPAs on these supports significantly increases the specific surface area, which is very important for heterogeneous catalysis processes. The supports also influence the catalytic activity of HPAs. Conventionally HPAs have been immobilized on various organic polymers such as resins [30,31], inert porous solids such as activated carbon [32,33], magnetite nanoparticles [34,35], or encapsulated in the pores and cavities of microporous and mesoporous materials such as zeolites, MCM-41 and SBA-15 [36–39]. The ship-in-a-bottle synthesis has become an efficient method for immobilizing homogeneous catalysts within the solid porous materials [40–44]. The concept of ship-in-a-bottle synthesis, first used by Herron [40], is to introduce reactants in the cages of porous materials to react within the cages and the products are physically entrapped inside the rigid cages. This procedure is a method of immobilization for species that can act as catalyst without the need for developing specific interactions with the surface of support. The advantage is that there is no covalent bond between the entrapped species and the support, which make them very similar to their homogeneous counterparts in terms of structure, activity and selectivity. Previously, Sulikowski and coworkers have separately succeeded in immobilizing HPAs in Y-type zeolite by directly synthesizing their molecules in the micropores of the zeolite [43,44]. Although this catalyst showed fairly high activities in liquid phase reactions which involve water, their usage is thought to be limited due to the fairly low stability of the support [44]. This drawback can be overcome by using alternative stable materials as the support, for example, SBA-type mesoporous materials. In recent years, due to its large cage, ordered pore structure, high surface area and high thermal stability, SBA-16 mesoporous material has been appeared to be one of the best candidates for catalytic support and packing materials for separation [45–48]. SBA-16 is a porous silica with large cage-like mesopores arranged in a three dimensional cubic body-centered Im3m symmetry. Due to its high thermal stability, high surface area, and large pore volume, SBA-16 can be regarded as a good support for the accommodation of catalytic active species such as HPAs. But, there is only one report on the immobilization of HPAs on SBA-16 material without investigation of its catalytic properties [48]. To the best of our knowledge, no attempt has been made to immobilize Wells-Dawson structured phosphotungstic acid (H6P2W18O62) onto the nanocages of SBA-16. In the present study, Wells-Dawson structured phosphotungstic acid was immobilized on mesoporous SBA-16 by ship-in-a-bottle method. The catalytic activity of the prepared material as heterogeneous catalyst was examined in the presence of H2O2 as green oxidant. The advantages of this system are the easy recovery of the solid catalyst at the end of reaction as well as good activity, selectivity and high stability in the epoxidation of olefins. Moreover, as it releases only water as by-product, the process is environmentally friendly. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instrumentation Pluronic copolymer F-127 (EO106PO70EO106) was purchased from Sigma Company. All other chemicals were purchased from Merck chemical company. All of the solvents were used after distillation. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on Perkin-Elmer Spectrum RXI FT-IR spectrometer using pellets of the materials diluted with KBr. Elemental analyses were performed by a VARIAN VISTA-MPX ICP-AES spectrometer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a SIEFERT XRD 3003 PTS diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (wavelength, λ=0.154nm). Thermogravimetric measurements were made on a Perkin Elmer Diamond Thermogravimeter. The temperature was increased to 700°C using a rate of 10°C/min in static air. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was performed using a Philips EM 208S instrument with an accelerating voltage of 100kV. Samples were prepared for TEM analysis by placing droplets of a suspension of the sample in acetone on a polymer microgrid supported on a Cu grid. Nitrogen sorption studies were performed at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196°C) using Quantachrome Nova 2200e, Version 7.11 Analyzer. Before the adsorption experiments the samples were outgassed under high vacuum at 120°C. All calculations were performed using the program of Quantachrome Nova 2200e surface area analyzer. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst The mesoporous material, SBA-16, was prepared according to the literature method [49] and calcined at 550°C for 6h to remove the surfactant from the mesopores. The neat H6P2W18O62 heteropoly acid was also synthesized in the homogeneous phase according to literature method [4]. Preparation of H6P2W18O62 heteropoly acid within the pores of SBA-16 was performed according to the following method: SBA-16 (1g, evacuated at 120°C for 8h) was suspended in a solution of Na2WO4 (0.82g) in distilled water (25ml) and stirred for 24h at room temperature. After addition of 1ml H3PO4 and HNO3, the suspension was refluxed for 24h. The solvent was evaporated and the resulting solid dried in vacuum oven for 24h. The surface modification of the obtained material with triethoxyoctylsilane was performed according to the literature method [50]. The obtained solid was added to a mixture containing dry toluene (5ml) and anhydrous pyridine (5ml). After addition of triethoxyoctylsilane (5mmol), the resulting suspension was refluxed for 24h under N2 atmosphere. The resulting solid was isolated by filtration and thoroughly washed with dichloromethane to remove any unreacted silylating reagent from the surface of the solid. Finally, the obtained solid was soxhlet extracted with distilled water and then dried in vacuum oven for 24h. 2.3 Catalytic epoxidation of olefins in the presence of the prepared catalyst Epoxidation of olefins was carried out in a 25ml round bottomed flask equipped with a condenser and a magnetic stirrer. In a typical procedure, 100mg of catalyst was added to a solution of olefin or allylic alcohol (8mmol) in acetonitrile (10ml), and 1.6ml 30% H2O2 (12.8mmol) as oxidant was added to the mixture. The reaction mixture was refluxed for appropriate time under nitrogen atmosphere. Samples were withdrawn periodically and were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (HP, Agilent 6890N) equipped with a capillary column (HP-5) and a FID detector. Products were quantified using isooctane (8.75mmol) as internal standard. GC–MS of the products were recorded using a Shimadzu-14A fitted with a capillary column (CBP5-M25). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of the heteropoly acid inside the nanocages of SBA-16 through ship-in-a-bottle method The preparation of Wells-Dawson structured heteropoly acid inside the nanocages of SBA-16 by ship-in-a-bottle method is outlined in Fig. 1 . Basically, it consists of first loading the Na2WO4 and then addition of H3PO4 and HNO3 followed by final assembly of the reactants in the nanocages. If the reactants were added simultaneously, an unfavourably large amount of heteropoly acid were formed out of the nanocages. In order to confine the heteropoly acid within the nanocages of SBA-16 and avoid from its leaching during the catalytic reaction, the pore entrance size should be smaller than the size of the heteropoly acid. Silylation is one of the most efficient methods for tuning the pore entrance of the mesoporous materials. Thus, the heteropoly acid incorporated SBA-16 material was silylated with triethoxyoctylsilane to tailor the pore entrance size of the mesopores. Earlier report indicated that silylation with this reagent results in reducing the pore entrance without blocking them [50]. It is interesting that based on the results of FT-IR and atomic absorption spectroscopies (not shown here), when the pore entrances of the SBA-16 are silylated in the first step, any attempt to immobilize the heteropoly acid through the ship-in-a-bottle synthesis within the mesopores of the octyl-modified SBA-16, oct-SBA-16, is unsuccessful. So, in the first step, the heteropoly acid was prepared within the nanocages and then the pore entrances were modified in the final step. 3.2 Characterization of the prepared materials The FT-IR spectra of pristine SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 materials as well as neat H6P2W18O62 heteropoly acid have been shown in Fig. 2 . In the FT-IR spectrum of H6P2W18O62@SBA-16, the four main absorption bands which are ascribed to stretching vibrations of heteropoly acids [51] can be observed at 1082cm−1 (νas,PO), 977cm−1 (ν as,WO), 895cm−1 (ν as,cornersharingWOW) and 804cm−1 (ν as,edgesharingWOW) which confirmed the encapsulation of the heteropoly acid within the nanocages of SBA-16 (Fig. 2c). Compared with bulk H6P2W18O62 (Fig. 2a), the observed small blue shift of ν as,cornersharingWOW and ν as,edgesharingWOW peaks in H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 indicates the relatively stronger interactions of bridging oxygens within the pore walls rather than terminal oxygens [52]. The peaks in the range of 2800–3000cm−1 can be assigned to the CH stretching vibrations of the CH2 groups of octyl groups. Also, the bands at 1400–1500cm−1 were assigned to the CH deformations confirming the successful silylation of the pore entrance of SBA-16. The strong broad band around 1000–1300cm−1 is due to asymmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si bonds of SBA-16. Two more bands at 800cm−1 and 472cm−1 can be ascribed to symmetric stretching and bending vibrations of SiOSi, respectively. ICP-AES spectroscopy showed that the soxhlet extracted H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 sample contain 0.061mmolheteropoly acid per gram of SBA-16 (Table 1 ) and further demonstrated the immobilization of heteropoly acid within the nanocages of SBA-16. Furthermore, the ICP-AES analysis shows P:W ratio (1:8.85) close to a Wells-Dawson structure (with P:W ratio of 1:9) rather than probable Keggin structure (with P:W ratio of 1:12). To investigate the pore structure of support after encapsulation of heteropoly acid, nitrogen adsorption experiment was performed at liquid nitrogen temperature. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of SBA-16 and encapsulated heteropoly acid samples are displayed in Fig. 3 a. Furthermore, in order to clarify the effect of silylation on the textural properties of the SBA-16, nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis on the heteropoly acid free octyl-modified SBA-16, oct-SBA-16, was performed and its isotherm has been shown in Fig. 3a. As can be seen in the adsorption isotherm of pure SBA-16 support, the uptake of N2 increases at high relative pressure and shows a hysteresis loop which exhibits type IV isotherm pattern with H2 hysteresis loop according to the Brunauer-Deming-Deming-Teller (BDDT) classification [53]. This type of isotherm and hysteresis loop is typical of materials with ink-bottle pores with interconnectivity in a 3D pore system and indicative of a cage-like cubic porous structure. The isotherm shows one step desorption branch, with high porosity characteristics, indicating the existence of an open pore structure. Similarly to the pure SBA-16, the octyl-SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 samples also show type IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis loops, indicating that these materials still maintain the cubic cage-type porous structure of the SBA-16 support. Compared with SBA-16, the inflection point of the oct-SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 samples shift slightly to lower relative pressures and the volume of adsorbed nitrogen decreased suggesting that the pore size is reduced by silylation with triethoxyoctylsilane and encapsulation of H6P2W18O62 heteropoly acid. The shape of the hysteresis loops, i.e. condensation step, becomes less vertical and the loop is less defined. Pore size distributions of SBA-16, octyl-SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 samples were obtained from the desorption branches of the isotherms using the Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) method and are shown in Fig. 3b. SBA-16 shows a monomodal distribution with a maximum located at 37Å indicating the presence of mesopores. On the other hand, oct-SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 samples present a monomodal distribution with the maxima centered at 36 and 30Å, respectively. The physical parameters of the samples such as SBET, pore volume, and BJH pore diameter are summarized in Table 2 . Determination of surface area was commonly based on the theory of multilayer adsorption developed by Brunauer, Emmett and Teller with the relative pressure (p/p0) in range of 0.05–0.30. The total pore volume was directly calculated from the volume of nitrogen held at the highest relative pressure (p/p0 =0.98), using 0.8081gcm−3 for the density of N2 in its normal liquid state. From the textural parameters listed in Table 2, it can be concluded that compared with SBA-16 and octyl-SBA-16, the surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 sample are sharply decreased, which can be attributed to the existence of heteropoly acids in the nanocages. The large decrease in the pore volume and BET surface area for H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 may be due to partial pores blocking by the H6P2W18O62 species as Tsoncheva et al. described [54]. The small angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 samples are shown in Fig. 4 . SBA-16 and H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 materials exhibit one (110) diffraction peak, indicating that the structure of mesoporous SBA-16 support remains intact after heteropoly acid immobilization. The (110) diffraction peak gradually decreased in intensity and its 2θ value gradually shifts to lower angle for H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 demonstrating occurrence of silylation and encapsulation of heteropoly acid within the nanocages of SBA-16. No peaks characteristic of H6P2W18O62 is detected in the wide angle region suggesting fine dispersion of heteropoly acid within the nanocages of SBA-16. The thermal behavior of the prepared H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 was investigated by TGA (red line) and DTA (blue line) analyses and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . According to these curves, the prepared material shows three different stages of mass reduction as a function of temperature. The first partial weight loss of about 7wt% is observed before temperature of 200°C, which can be attributed to the loss of physisorbed water molecules. As a result of the endothermic nature of the evaporation of adsorbed water molecules the corresponding DTA curve in this region is endothermic. The second major weight loss of about 5wt% appeared at the temperature range of 250–400°C is assigned to the decomposition of organic species i.e. octyl groups. The final step of about 7wt% weight loss at about 540°C can be attributed to collapse of the heteropoly acid structure and crystallization of the resulting oxides. The morphology and microstructure of the prepared material are revealed by TEM analysis (Fig. 6 ). From Fig. 6, one can clearly observe a highly ordered mesoporous structure and a narrow pore distribution can be also observed. This indicates that the mesoporous structure of SBA-16 is maintained after the encapsulation of H6P2W18O62 heteropoly acid. 3.3 Catalytic activity of the prepared catalyst in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols with H2O2 Catalytic activity of the immobilized heteropoly acid was evaluated in the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols with H2O2 and the results have been given in Fig. 7 . As can be seen in Fig. 7, the prepared H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 can act as active and selective catalyst in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols. The selectivities of the reactions toward the production of epoxides were found to be close to 100% in all of the entries of Fig. 7. In order to clear up the catalytic effect of the prepared H6P2W18O62@SBA-16, the epoxidation of cyclooctene in the presence of parent SBA-16 and blank (no catalyst) as well as bulk heteropoly acid were investigated and the results have been included in Table 3 . As can be seen in this Table, no significant reaction occurred in the absence of the catalyst or in the presence of SBA-16 itself. The effect of catalyst amount on the conversion of the cycooctene was also investigated and the results have been given in Table 3. Furthermore, the effect of different heteropolyacid loading and hydrogen peroxide amount on the epoxidation of cyclootene was investigated and the results are shown in Tables 4 and 5 . As can be seen, lower loading of heteropolyacid results in lower conversions of the epoxidation reaction. We did not investigate the higher loading of heteropolyacid in order to prevent the phase separation of the heteropolyacid and also blocking of the pores. On the other hand, with increasing the H2O2:cyclooctene ratio the conversion is increased. As a result of nonproductive decomposition of H2O2 during the reaction, it seems necessary to use excess amount of H2O2 with respect to the olefin. Furthermore, the reactivities of the olefins in the epoxidation reaction increase in the order of cyclooctene> cyclohexene>1-hexene>1-octene which shows that the internal double bond olefins with higher electron density are more reactive than terminal ones. Earlier reports have shown that the oxidizing species in the epoxidation of olefins with hydrogen peroxide in the presence of tungsten compounds has electrophilic character. So, increasing the nucleophilicity of the double bond increases the reaction rate. The experimental results indicate that the mechanism for the oxygen-transfer step from the tungsten-peroxo complex to the olefin involves attack of the olefin on one of the peroxygens of the complex [55,56]. The proposed mechanism for the epoxidation of olefins was shown in Scheme 1 . Furthermore, allylic alcohols are more reactive than simple olefins. This is probably due to the participation of hydroxyl group in approaching the double bond to the electrophilic oxygen center. The catalytic activity of the prepared heterogeneous catalyst was compared with that of the corresponding homogeneous analogue under the same conditions. The amount of free H6P2W18O62 used in entry 3 of Table 3 corresponds to the amount of H6P2W18O62 immobilized in 100mg of the H6P2W18O62@SBA-16 catalyst. As can be concluded from Fig. 7 and Table 3, the reaction rates in the presence of the prepared heterogeneous catalyst were comparable to those of homogeneous one. For example, after 8h the conversion of olefin in the presence of neat H6P2W18O62 is 76% in comparison with 74% in the case of H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. This fact indicates that the homogeneous catalyst can be heterogenized within the nanocages of SBA-16 with retention of the catalyst performance. In order to assess the possible catalytic contribution of the solubilized heteropoly acid species, the reaction mixture in the epoxidation of cyclooctene was filtered off after 8h reaction and then left to react for a further 24h. As can be observed in Table 6 , in this time interval the cyclooctene conversion rose only 3% suggesting that there is no any significant heteropoly acid species in the solution and the catalytic reaction is truly heterogeneous in nature. On the other hand, no tungsten species was detected in the solution by ICP-AES. The recyclability of the catalyst was investigated after separation of the catalyst from reaction mixture at the end of the reaction and washing with acetonitrile. The recovered catalyst was reused for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol and the obtained results are given in Fig. 8 . The results show that the activity does not decrease in a major way at least for five uses of the H6P2W18O62@SBA-16. The ICP-AES analyses of the recycled catalysts show no significant loss of the tungsten content after 5 successive catalytic cycles (Table 1). 4 Conclusions This work provides an efficient and easy method for designation of a novel and selective heterogeneous catalyst for epoxidation of olefins. SBA-16 was shown to be effective support for the immobilization of Wells-Dawson structured phosphotungstic acid. The analyses results confirmed the efficient immobilization of H6P2W18O62 inside the nanocages of SBA-16. The catalyst was shown to be active and selective in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols with hydrogen peroxide. The epoxidation was completely stopped by the catalyst removal. It was confirmed by ICP-AES analyses that the catalyst has no leaching and no soluble tungsten species could be detected in the filtrate. Furthermore, the catalyst is heterogeneous and could be easily recovered by the filtration and reused several times in the epoxidation of cyclooctene without major loss of the catalytic activity and selectivity. The prepared catalyst showed comparable catalytic activity with supported Polyoxometalate catalysts in H2O2-based olefin epoxidation. coredata.dc:description: Wells-Dawson structured heteropoly acid (H6P2W18O64) was immobilized into the SBA-16 mesoporous material by ship-in-a-bottle method. The obtained material was characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission (ICP-AES) spectroscopies, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), nitrogen adsorption–desorption analysis, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA-DTA). The results indicated that the surface area of SBA-16 support decreased after immobilization of the heteropoly acid and next modification with silylating agent. The prepared material exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the epoxidation of olefins and allylic alcohols in the presence of hydrogen peroxide as green oxidant. The catalyst showed all of the expected advantages of the heterogeneous systems and was shown to be recoverable and reusable several times without major loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Wells-Dawson heteropoly acid immobilized inside the nanocages of SBA-16 with ship-in-a-bottle method: A new recoverable catalyst for the epoxidation of olefins
